repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Third Technical Assistance
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Third Technical
            Assistance Credit Project for Pakistan was satisfactory. The
            project achieved most of its specific objectives, its impact
            on institutional development was partially successful,
            sustainability is likely, and the performance of both the
            Bank and Borrower was satisfactory. Several lessons can be
            learned from this project. First, for future TA projects,
            the Bank's monitoring and progress report requirements
            should be simplified and made less time consuming. Second,
            in order to avoid duplication of the effort involved in the
            selection of consultants and to enable the sub-projects to
            contribute to the development of the Government's
            structural reform program in a more effective and timely
            manner, a simplified set of procedures needs to be
            developed. Third, if the Bank is to be involved with the
            functioning of a future technical assistance project,
            additional staff weeks should be devoted to field
            supervision of the TA credit. Fourth, effective control of
            any such future general purpose TA credits should be
            centralized in the agency responsible for policy planning in
            the Government and the Project Director of the TAPC should
            be given greater authority to decide on certain matters.
            Fifth, for each sub-project, one organization should be
            asked to take primary technical and administrative
            responsibility for the product. Finally, it may be desirable
            to modify the design of future TA projects and restrict
            their scope to only policy and reform issues.

docna.cdata!:
Pakistan - Third Technical Assistance
            Project : Credit 1755 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Pakistan - Third Technical
            Assistance Project : Credit 1755 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Technical Assistance Credit
            Project will support the Government in formulating and
            implementing programs of structural and policy reform in key
            sectors and subsectors of the economy, and in maintaining an
            environment of sound macro-economic management. Financing
            will be provided for studies, specialized consultancies,
            training and equipment necessary for building up the
            institutional capacity to design and implement policy
            reforms on a permanent basis. The project will assist the
            Government in the areas of macro-economic management,
            resource mobilization, agricultural policy, industrial
            strategy, and energy, transport, urban, and education sector
            policies. Given the Government's experience in
            implementing two previous technical assistance projects,
            there are no major project implementation risks anticipated.
            There is the possibility, however, that the Government may
            not implement some policy reform proposals, or may proceed
            more slowly than desirable.
